awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Thomas Polstra is "Measuring and Relating Singularities in Prime Characteristic Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Utah, and the sponsoring scientist is Karl Schwede.

por.por_cntn:
The PI's investigations yielded developments in the theory of Hilbert-Kunz multiplicity and F-signature, both of which are numerical invariants used to understand and relate singularities of prime characterisitic rings and algebraic varieties. More specifically, the behavior of these invariants under birational morphisms (with Ma, Schwede, and Tucker), perturbations and localization (with Smirnov), and in a non-local setting (with De Stefani and Yao) were expolored. The PI's investigations yielded new insight to the theory of maximal Cohen-Macaulay modules which yielded corollaries on the divisor class group of certain rings. The PI also explored the structure of local cohomology modules over prime characteristic rings. The notion of an F-nilpotent ring was developed (with Quy, Kenkel, Maddox, and Simpson). The theory of compatible ideals in F-pure rings was developed (with Schwede). The PI (with Carvajal-Rojas, Ma, Schwede, and Tucker) provided classification theorems of mixed characteristic rational double points. The most significant developement of the PI was produced with Aberbach and provided new cases of the weak implies strong conjecture from tight closure theory. The PI served the mathematical community by organizing weekly math circles, developing an undergraduate topics course, teaching graduate student summer schools, referreeing research articles, and mentoring undergraduate students (Murray and Martin).
